verses.text: Praise the LORD! Praise the name of the LORD; give praise, you servants of the LORD,
verses.comment: The psalm begins as a call to worship, specifically directed to those who serve in the temple, anticipating the role of a set-apart, ordained ministry in the worship life of the people of God.

verses.text: who stand in the house of the LORD, in the courts of the house of our God!
verses.comment: The focus on the house and courts of God underlines the continuity of worship centered at a holy place, pointing forward to forms of worship that emphasize God’s enduring presence in His sanctuary.

verses.text: Praise the LORD, for the LORD is good; sing praises to his name, for it is pleasant!
verses.comment: Emphasizes both the goodness of God and the inherent joy and beauty of worship—a foundational principle for both Old and New Testament worship.

verses.text: For the LORD has chosen Jacob for himself, Israel as his treasured possession.
verses.comment: The doctrine of divine election is clear here—God freely chooses and treasures His people (cf. 1 Peter 2:9), pointing to a communal identity rooted in being set apart and specially chosen.

verses.text: For I know that the LORD is great, and our Lord is above all gods.
verses.comment: Affirms monotheism and God’s supremacy over any so-called gods, which ties into later developments in Christian doctrine emphasizing the one true God revealed most fully in Christ.

verses.text: Whatever the LORD pleases, he does, in heaven and on earth, in the seas and all the deeps.
verses.comment: God’s absolute sovereignty and creative power are stressed—echoing the creation account and anticipating an understanding of providence that shapes Christian confidence in God’s will being active everywhere.

verses.text: He causes the clouds to rise from the ends of the earth; he makes lightning for the rain and brings forth the wind from his storehouses.
verses.comment: Highlights God’s ongoing governance of creation, connecting to biblical themes of God’s creative Word sustaining the world (see Heb. 1:3).

verses.text: He struck down the firstborn of Egypt, both of man and beast;
verses.comment: A reference to the Exodus, showing God’s ability to judge and redeem—foreshadowing deliverance themes found in the New Testament.

verses.text: He sent signs and wonders into your midst, O Egypt, upon Pharaoh and all his servants.
verses.comment: Recalls the miracles during the Exodus, reinforcing trust in God’s power and the importance of remembering the acts of God in salvation history.

verses.text: He struck down many nations and killed mighty kings,
verses.comment: Highlights God’s judgment on the nations for the sake of His people, prefiguring Christ’s victory over sin and spiritual enemies.

verses.text: Sihon, king of the Amorites, and Og, king of Bashan, and all the kingdoms of Canaan,
verses.comment: Specific examples of God’s deliverance for Israel, showing how God works through history to fulfill His promises.

verses.text: and gave their land as a heritage, a heritage to Israel his people.
verses.comment: Emphasizes inheritance, which has both literal and spiritual significance—pointing forward to the promise of a lasting heritage and unity for the people of God.

verses.text: Your name, O LORD, endures forever, your fame, O LORD, throughout all generations.
verses.comment: God’s eternal name points to His unchanging nature, anticipating Jesus’ own claim to share in God’s eternal identity (John 8:58).

verses.text: For the LORD will vindicate his people and have compassion on his servants.
verses.comment: Underscores God’s faithfulness and mercy. The Lord’s compassion connects to New Testament passages where Jesus is moved by compassion for God’s people.

verses.text: The idols of the nations are silver and gold, the work of human hands.
verses.comment: Contrasts the living God with lifeless idols, reinforcing the necessity of worship directed towards the true God in the way He establishes.

verses.text: They have mouths, but do not speak; they have eyes, but do not see;
verses.comment: Human-made idols are powerless, in contrast to the living, speaking God, who continues to reveal Himself to His people throughout salvation history.

verses.text: they have ears, but do not hear, nor is there any breath in their mouths.
verses.comment: The theme of lifelessness in idols prepares for a fuller revelation of the God who, by His Spirit, gives life and breath, preparing for the New Covenant understanding.

verses.text: Those who make them become like them, so do all who trust in them.
verses.comment: Spiritual principle: people grow to resemble what they worship, underscoring the importance of rightly ordered worship and fidelity to the living God.

verses.text: O house of Israel, bless the LORD! O house of Aaron, bless the LORD!
verses.comment: All the people, including the priestly house of Aaron, are called to bless God, hinting toward God’s design of an enduring, ordered priesthood.

verses.text: O house of Levi, bless the LORD! You who fear the LORD, bless the LORD!
verses.comment: God’s blessing is to be proclaimed by both those specifically set apart for sacred service and by all the faithful, pointing to unity in the worshiping community.

verses.text: Blessed be the LORD from Zion, he who dwells in Jerusalem! Praise the LORD!
verses.comment: Ends by situating God’s dwelling in Zion/Jerusalem, a foreshadowing of God’s special presence among His people, fulfilled in the New Testament as Christ establishes the community of believers as the place where God dwells most fully.
